html:
• anchor

    Image: © WAX Architectural Visualizations

    The design framework for the forthcoming Austin Light Rail transportation system in the Texas state capital has been unveiled by the Austin Transit Partnership (ATP) in collaboration with UNStudio, Gehl, and HKS. 

    The 15-station Phase 1 plan includes a new bridge over Lady Bird Lake and expanded green infrastructure. The ATP will say it will 'prioritize intuitive, multimodal connectivity" as an "expression" of the city’s unique identity, with each station tailored to its surrounding neighborhood and a full integration of pedestrian, cycling, and transit networks into its design.

    The project, therefore, "goes beyond infrastructure," in the words of the ATP and Amsterdam-based firm. They further emphasized the project’s importance in terms of its enhancements to the existing urban realm (e.g. new tree-lined streets and shaded public areas). The network will cover about 10 miles once it begins operation. 

    It offers UNStudio the opportunity to add to a portfolio of similar award-winning projects for Los Angeles, Melbourne, the Netherlands, Doha, and Beijing. Some outlets have said the $7 billion light rail expects to open in 2033 after a construction start in 2027.

    "Our Cognitive Experience design approach means we can incorporate how users think and react to certain situations directly into our designs,” Ben van Berkel, the founder and principal architect at UNStudio said finally.

    The publication of details for the Austin project joins last month's announcement of the Expo 2020 site's redevelopment and the completion of the firm's first South American project in São Paulo in September.
